keyTakeAways: Seven skeletons found in a mass grave in Croatia were identified as ancient Roman soldiers who lived approximately 1,700 years ago.
The men were aged between 36 and 50 years, taller-than-average, and physically robust, indicating a strong and active lifestyle.
Their diets were primarily vegetarian, with some consumption of meat and seafood, reflecting the dietary patterns of Roman soldiers or urban populations.
All individuals showed various healed and unhealed injuries, including blunt force trauma and puncture wounds likely caused by arrows or spear tips.
All men exhibited signs of pulmonary disease in their final days, suggesting chronic illness or environmental stress prior to death.
DNA analysis revealed mixed ancestry, indicating the soldiers were not local to the region of Mursa, possibly foreign recruits or soldiers from other parts of the Empire.
The mass burial site was originally a water well, which is unusual for Roman times, as mass graves were not customary in the Roman Empire.
The skeletons were found in disarray, suggesting they were thrown into the well during a mass casualty event, such as a battle during the Crisis of the Third Century.
The research supports the theory that these soldiers died in the Battle of Mursa in 260 CE, during a period of political instability and military conflict in the Roman Empire.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study has identified seven skeletons found in a mass grave in Croatia's Osijek region as ancient Roman soldiers who lived around 1,700 years ago. The men, aged between 36 and 50, were physically robust and showed signs of injuries from blunt force trauma and arrow-like puncture wounds, indicating they died during violent conflict. DNA analysis revealed mixed ancestry, suggesting they were not local to the area. Researchers believe the soldiers died during the Crisis of the Third Century, specifically in the 260 CE Battle of Mursa, when the Roman Empire faced internal instability and civil wars. The burial site was originally a water well, which is highly unusual for Roman times, indicating a mass casualty event. The findings provide significant insight into military life, combat, and mortality in the Roman Empire, and highlight the importance of archaeological research in understanding historical events.
title: Croatia: Skeletons in mass grave are ancient Roman soldiers, study finds
